Award.AbstractNarration:
The main aim of this proposal is to investigate a few questions in birational geometry. The first parts intends to study rationally connected varieties, which are the simplest algebraic varieties from many points of view. For non-proper varieties, there are various definitions of rational connectedness.
The proposer will study their relations. He will also continue his study on the arithmetic property of rationally connected varieties. The other parts focus on the boundedness type questions of varieties or pairs. Especially, when the pair is of log general type, the PI investigator is trying to establish the uniform properties of their volumes.

Algebraic varieties are roughly speaking the figures described by the solutions of polynomials. Algebraic geometry is a subject which aims to classify all algebraic varieties. In the birational sense, algebraic varieties are built up by some specific types of varieties. Rationally connected varieties and general type varieties are such fundamental building blocks. To understand them will largely improve our understanding of all algebraic varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to understand the geometric structure of higher dimensional varieties. The latter is the space of solutions to a polynomial equations system. To understand such its geometry is one of the most fundament problems in mathematics, and form the core of the subject called algebraic geometry. Higher dimensional geometry is the field in algebraic geometry, which gives a structural theory of building any algebraic varieties by blocks of a few basic types. Its study will largely improve people's understanding of all algebraic varieties. 

 

In this project, with his collaborators, the PI has proved a number of results in higher dimensional geometry, including solving some longstanding conjectures and open problems, and also open some new directions. The questions which have been solved in this project include the birational boundedness of log general type pairs, the ACC conjecture of log canonical thresholds, the properness of KSBA moduli functor, the non-existence of chow stable compactification of Gieseker spaces. The project has also openned the new direction of studying the topology of dual complexes arised in birational geometry. 

 

These results have a major influence in higher dimensional geometry, including moduli theory, singularity theory etc. It draws connections between different fields in mathematics. It has inspired many new work in a wide range of mathematical fields. A large number of mathematicians, including graduate students and post-docs, are doing their research based on the study initiated in this work.
